subject: Art
title: Brainstorming Methods
description: Structured techniques for generating ideas beyond the first obvious one.

hook.text: 'Just brainstorm' is terrible advice without a method. Effective brainstorming uses structured techniques that push past the obvious. Unstructured 'think of ideas' produces clichÃ©s. Structured methods produce surprises.

buildup.text: Methods: mind mapping (central idea â†’ branches â†’ sub-branches), SCAMPER (Substitute, Combine, Adapt, Modify, Put to other use, Eliminate, Reverse), random word association (connect a random word to your problem), and worst idea first (deliberately generate bad ideas, then flip them).

discovery.text: Mind mapping works because it's visual and associative: one idea triggers the next. Start with the central concept, write related ideas around it, then branch from THOSE. The connections at the outer edges are where original ideas live.

twist.text: 'Worst idea' brainstorming is counterintuitively powerful: asking 'what's the worst solution?' removes the pressure of being good. People generate ideas freely â€” and then inverting the worst ideas often reveals genuinely brilliant approaches.

climax.text: Try all three: for the prompt 'design a poster about water conservation,' do a mind map (3 min), SCAMPER on your best idea (3 min), and random word association with the word 'telescope' (3 min). Compare results â€” the unexpected connections win.

punchline.text: Brainstorming without structure is just daydreaming. Add a method and the ideas multiply.

quiz.question: Why does the 'worst idea' brainstorming method work?
options: Removing the pressure to be good frees people to generate ideas freely, and inverting bad ideas often reveals brilliant approaches
